history.content:
Dear all, 
 
Given the rigor of our programs and the unsettling events happening across our state and country, taking care of ourselves is as important as ever. Therefore, our staff wanted to take a moment to share some resources with you. Some of these helped me as an Cal undergraduate; others I wish I'd have known about. 
 
I really encourage you to set aside some time to review this email in its entirety and consider engaging with some of the resources listed. I promise some will be new to you.
 
Very Best Wishes,
Nicole 
Undergraduate Advisor for CS and EECS majors
 
 
Seeking Help
Individuals vary in their ability to cope with stressful situations. If at any time you are having stress-related problems that persist or interfere with your health or well-being, especially if you feel overwhelmed, you may want to seek professional assistance. Here are two great resources:
 
Dr. Shuangmei (Christine) Zhou is a licensed staff psychologist from Counseling and Psychological Services (CPS) and is also the “in-house” psychologist for the College of Engineering. She can help with stress and anxiety, depressed moods, procrastination, time management, and many other concerns. She is available to meet with EECS, CS declared/intended, and other technical majors.
 • Email her at christinez@uhs.berkeley.edu or call 510-643-7850 to schedule an appointment
 • Non-emergency drop-in hours on Tuesdays 2pm-4pm and Wednesdays 10am-12pm in 241 Bechtel 
 • If Christine is not available when you need help, please feel free to speak with a different counselor at Tang Center (see below)

UHS Counseling Psychological Services, 2222 Bancroft Way. All registered UC Berkeley undergraduate and graduate students are eligible for CPS services, regardless of their insurance coverage.
 • Call (510) 642-9494 or go online to get started and schedule an appointment.
 • Walk-in appointments available for urgent concerns: 10am-5pm Monday - Friday
 
Academic Support
Our department is really fortunate to have lots of students that care about helping their peers.Tutoring is available free of charge from a number of sources.  If you think you might need tutoring help, don’t worry! Many of our students find they need to work with a tutor at some point during their academic career. It is important to seek academic assistance early if you feel that you need it. More information here.
 
Bouncing Back
The EECS Department Resiliency project exists for times of difficulty. This new project is aimed at helping students learn from failure and instilling a sense of hope, belonging, and bravery. Our goal is to help change the perception of failure from something to be avoided at all costs to something that has meaning, purpose, and value.
 
Staying Healthy
From financial worries and academic pressures, to personal matters and concerns about flu season, we are all dealing with daily stressors that can affect healthy habits. Use these guides to prioritize yourself and stay healthy!
  • Eating Well
  • Managing the Stress of Change and Transition
  • Headaches and Muscle Tension
  • Sleeping Soundly
  • Fitting Fitness In
  • Managing Anxiety
  • Tang Center's Massage Chair
  • Recreational Sports: Exercise classes, personal trainers, massage services, and low-cost memberships to campus facilities
Remember, if you have any questions you can always contact any member of the EECS Center for Student Affairs team. We are here for you!
